item.description:
Rocket is casino style card game created by the makers of the game Pairs. The game can be played with any Pairs playing card deck, but was specially designed and introduced with the Bar Maids deck.

Equipment: A Pairs deck, and chips or coins for gambling.

Flow of Play:

Rocket is structured as a casino table game.

All players are playing against the dealer (not each other), and the dealer plays by fixed rules. In a home game, players should take turns being the dealer. There is a slight advantage for the dealer, so the game is only fair when the deal passes around the table.

The Deck:
You can play Rocket with a single Pairs deck, or up to 8 Pairs decks shuffled together. The deck should be reshuffled when approximately 20% remains.

The Bet:
 To begin, each player must place a bet. Different players can bet different amounts. A bet must be divisible by 10 units, because all payouts will be based on 1/10 of the bet. The dealer agrees to cover bets of any size, up to a maximum bet agreed upon by all players.

The Starting Deal:
Deal one card face up to each player, and then to the dealer. Play begins on the dealer’s left.

Using a Button:
Casinos may wish to start each hand with the low card,rather than on the dealer’s left. In this case, use a button to designate the starting position, and break ties by choosing the player closest to the left of the previous button (rather than by dealing an extra card). Under these rules, the dealer still acts last.

Player’s Turn:
Each player is playing against the dealer only. In turn, players may either fold or hit. All players act before the dealer.

Folding: 
When you fold (similar to surrender in blackjack), you are paying to get out of the game. Pay the dealer a fraction of your bet, which is 1/10 of the total bet multiplied by the lowest card in either your stack or the dealer’s.

For example, if your bet is 20 coins, and the lowest card between you and the dealer is a 4, you can fold by paying 2 x 4 = 8 coins. You retrieve the remainder of your bet.

Hitting: 
When you hit, you are staying in, and trying not to get a pair. Take one card, faceup. If you don’t pair up, you are safe. If you get a pair, you lose, and must pay that number, multiplied by 1/10 of your bet. For example, if you have bet 20 coins and get a pair of 8’s, you pay 2 x 8 = 16 coins.

Dealer’s Turn: 
The dealer always acts last, and plays by a diff erent set of rules:

Dealer Must Hit: 
The dealer always hits (she cannot fold).

Dealer Pair: 
When the dealer catches a pair, she pays all surviving players that amount, multiplied by 1/10 of their bet.
For example, if the dealer catches 7-7, and your bet was 50, the dealer pays you 5 x 7 = 35 coins. (You also keep your bet.)

Death Card: 
A 3 is sudden death for the dealer. The dealer loses immediately if she gets a 3, even on her first card. Th is pays all bets at 3/10 (as if the dealer caught a pair of 3’s). Note: A 3 is not lethal to players, only the dealer.

Continuing:
If the dealer doesn’t pair up or catch a 3, play resumes with the first player. The game continues until all players either catch a pair or fold, or until the dealer pairs up or catches a 3.

Realistic football (soccer) simulation using magnetic board and pawns.
3 difficulty levels give a gameplay from a simple family game to real pedagogic and professional simulation.

With the first level of difficulty, each player gets a maximum of 5 actions per turn and must choose between attack, defense, shooting attempt, shooting, shooting defense and goalkeeper.

A special dice thrown give the result of each action and let the players know if it result with a goal or not after the succeded actions were simulated moving the pawns and the ball directely on the board.

The second and third levels of difficulty add more specifics and complex rules to the first ones by introducing real professional and international rules as corner, free-kick, offside, penalty and throw in.

Each player get 1 minute for its turn and the game can be set for 1 ou 2 45 minutes half times.

As a real soccer match, the best goal scored player is the winner.

Scrabble 360 or Turnspell is a Scrabble-like word building game. The main difference is that instead of having a hand of letter tiles and a common board, players have personal boards and they draft letters from a common pool.

On each turn, each player selects one letter tile from the four available to them on the central board. Players then place that letter on their personal game board. Empty spaces on the central board are filled randomly from the bag, then the board is rotated clockwise and players select a new letter tile from those available to them.

Players are attempting to build four letter words only. Once a four letter word is completed, that word is immediately scored and the letter tiles are returned to the bag. The first player to 44 points is the winner.

—user summary

Lowdown is a traditional card game in the Golf family. The object of the game is to have the lowest score. Players are dealt a 3x3 grid of face down cards. Players take turns drawing a card from the deck or discard pile to replace the cards in their grid. Each card has a number value, the higher the value the worse the card. Action cards such as Peek, Steal, and Swap allow players to rearrange their grid and take cards from other players. The hand ends once one player's cards are all face up. Then players add up the total value of their cards. Multiple hands are played, and once one player reaches 50 points, the player with the fewest points wins the game.

item.description:
In the trick-taking game Texas Showdown, originally published as Strife, you want to avoid taking tricks as skillfully as you can, but playing off-suit might not keep you safe as the suit can change during the trick, possibly stinging you in the end.

Before play, all the cards are distributed evenly among the players. Once a player leads a single card for the first trick, all other players must play a card of the same suit, if possible. If a player can't play on suit, they can play a card of any color — but after they do this, all subsequent players can play a card of either matching color (or possibly a third color if they have neither of the first two).

Once all players have played to the trick, you see which color has been played most frequently in the trick. Whoever played the highest card of this color wins the trick. If two or more colors are tied, then the color with the highest sum counts as the winner.

You play several rounds until someone reaches the target number of tricks taken. At that point, whoever has captured the fewest tricks wins!

item.description:
Place your Posse Cards in front of your draw pile with the cowboy facing the opposite player.
Pull 3 randomly drawn cards from you number cards. Next roll the die to match the cards. If the card and die match, move that number card up to the hit area, reminding you that you have secured one shot. If you match 2 cards with one roll, you receive the Jam Card. (For one turn you only have 2 cards to roll to match.)

If at any time one player is ever 2 cards ahead, the opposing player "feels desperate" and takes the Quick Draw Card and goes twice for one turn. If no cards are matched, then replace any card of your choice with a randomly drawn card from the draw pile. When ever 4 cards have hit, then one Posse Card is turned so that the Grave is facing the opposite player.

In Dreamcatcher it is up to you to compete with your fellow gods of the Dream World to protect the minds of mortal man. Through luck, skill and the help of your dream power will you be able to acquire nightmares otherwise bound for the human realm.

Every round new nightmares are made available to bet on using your finite amount of dream power cards combined with action cards. Based on player order, rarity of nightmares currently available and who is running ahead multiple strategies, and a bit of luck, are needed to come out victorious.

Dreamcatcher is a fast paced bluffing deduction card game for 2-6 players.

item.description:
In Korocchi!, you try to find the correct card that is determined by two (or three) unique dice, and whoever touches the correct card first score points. Each of the two dice in the basic game has two pieces of information:

• Color die: Shows you the outside color and inside color.
• Shape die: Shows you the outside shape and the inside shape.

Three different creatures (cat, bat and obake) are depicted on the cards, with these creatures appearing in three colors. Each card depicts one large creature in one color holding a tiny creature in another color. By pairing the two dice, you know precisely which one card to touch from all those face up on the table.

For an additional challenge, you can roll the third die as well. The faces on this die might just show that you play as normal scoring one or two points, or it might show the shapes or colors being reversed — which means you need to look for the opposite card (sort of) instead.

Players travel around a world they created one card at a time. Players grab ants and race home before other players can garb the.m You can attack other aardvarks, build a home, and raid their other aardvark homes to steal ants. Be the first player to get three ants safely home and keep them there to win.

The cards in the game are used for all elements of play, building the map, moving the players, constructing houses, and attack others.

Vers is a freestyle rap based card game where the players compete against each other to see which can create the best freestyle rap, but it uses a template system that makes it accessible to anyone.

The game's mission is to make freestyle rap accessible to anyone. From 7 year old girls to 71 year old grandparents, anyone can freestyle in this party game.

From the website:
A player might get a category like "Taco"
And then a base card like "Hate, Great, Appreciate"
And then one might rhyme:

"There's a taco in my mouth and it's filled with hate,
lettuce and cheese and it's looking great
but the beef is sour I cannot appreciate."

Each player would rap using a different category card and the player with the best rap would win, as chosen in an Apples to Apples style.

name.value: Clockwork Memolion (クロックワークメモリオン)

item.description:
In the year 1240 Princess Ikio proclaimed all men must find her the Super Unicorn. In order to lure the Super Unicorn, players will roll dice and vie for the special stars needed to complete their search.

In clockwise order, players take turns rolling all dice available, and must lock in dice on up to three different different stacks of cards available or on cards they have earned during the game. They may repeat this process until they want to pass. If they fail to roll a die or dice that can be used, their turn ends immediately. When the stack of cards on the highest rated card is is depleted, the player with the most stars on their face up cards wins the game.

name.value: The Princess and the Dragon Game

item.description: The Princess and the Dragon Game is an educational game for children teaching reading and matching skills. There are six different games, each of which involves collecting cards to fill the spaces on a board. They involve combinations of matching pictures to words or words to pictures. Some allow players to pick any card, others require them to pick off the top of a stack. One game involves miming words, and another requires players to come up with synonyms.

Help Dory find her family and friends! Dory and her friends are playing Hide and Seek. Where are they hiding? Be the first to find three, and you win.

The game is played on a large board printed 19" x 28" board printed with a pattern of dots designed to obscure pictures of the movie characters. Each player has a diving-mask-shaped viewer designed to reveal the character's picture. Players take turns turning over a card depicting a movie character. Players then race to use their viewers to find that character on the board. The player who finds the character claims the card. First player to three cards wins.
Monroviaopoly is a city-themed Monopoly clone with a Monrovia, California theme. Spaces on the board represent local businesses and landmarks.

To reach the peak of the fiery volcano, just identify the correct action words--but watch out for treacherous rock slides!

Verb Volcano is an educational game designed to teach verb forms and tenses. Each player chooses a card with a sentence and several possible verbs that could complete it. If they answer correctly, they spin a spinner to move up a track toward the top of the volcano. Spaces along the track may move players forward or back or grant an extra spin. The first player to reach the top of the volcano wins.

Visions is a competitive game where the players collect cards that show clocks. They play the clocks to connect other cards via the hands of the clocks with their mental center. Those other cards represent different topics which belong to family Yates: ancestors, places where they lived, rooms where they used to be and their collection of jewels. While the players are visionary talented people, they try to help family Yates finding out what curse lies on them.

By connecting the family cards at the right time (represented by the clock cards) with their mental center the players gain victory points, visionary power and vision parts in different colors. Each player has got a vision card with a 3x3 pattern where they place the vision parts according to the rules. The players get victory points for full rows and columns.

The players may use the visionary power to change it into benefits, for example reducing the cost to connect family cards with the mental center or getting additional vision parts.
At a given time the player with the fewest victory points chooses a sort of visionary power and all benefits which are connected to this power will be more expensive for the rest of the game and all players have to deal with this limitation.

One family card lies at a special position and can't be connected directly with the mental center but it is possible to connect the card through the other family cards with the center to get the benefits and the chance to force other players to swap vision parts and/or visionary power.

The players also have to try to solve a master vision with the vision parts to get extra points and offer the best help for family Yates. Only the one with the most victory points is able to give them the chance to break the curse.

item.description:
In Big Bang 13.7, you become one of the universe's creators, playing with celestial bodies such as colored planets, stars, asteroids, comets, and astronomic phenomena such as supernovas, wormholes and superdestructive black holes. While the universe expands, you can also cause orbits, eclipses, hyperspace, or even the mysterious and almost unknown dark energy. Your goal? Align celestial bodies while a cosmic clock is ticking the passing of time…in millions of years!

In more detail, the game is composed by hexagonal pieces: 48 celestial bodies of four types (planets, stars, asteroids and comets), with four colors (yellow, orange, red and blue) and three backgrounds (empty space, stars and galaxy). There are astronomical phenomena pieces (supernova, black hole and wormholes) and special actions (orbit, eclipse, hyperspace and dark energy). Finally, a cosmic clock will tick the passing of time and players' turn.

Before the game starts, each player takes two hidden objective cards: a celestial body type and a color. During the game, the player scores victory points by aligning three or more celestial bodies consecutively of their own type or color.

The game starts at moment zero of the universe 13.7 billion years ago, with someone placing the first piece: the Big Bang! On a turn, the player has to place one of the four available pieces below the cosmic clock. Two rules are mandatory to place a piece in the universe:


 The piece must be adjacent to at least two pieces and at least one of them has to be a celestial body.
 The celestial body has to have a common characteristic with all the adjacent celestial bodies: same type, same color, or same background.


Once the game runs out of available pieces and all of them are placed in the universe, the game ends. The players reveal their objective cards and count their victory points based on the alignments according to their two objective cards. Whoever has the most points wins. In case of a tie, the player who is the most behind on the cosmic clock — that is, the one who has invested fewer millions of years — wins.

item.description:
Lotus Dimension is a tabletop role-playing game (RPG).

Players have to solve all the challenges the 
game thrown at them using nonviolent means?
What if a game drew on amazing sci-fi and fantasy storytelling while also incorporating principles of nonviolence inspired by peaceful protests, historical leaders and the tenets of peaceful philosophical practices?

And what if it offered players a way to visualize and role-play solutions to wildly imagined problems, responding to and replacing violence and weaponry with empathy and ingenuity?

Be the first to complete your paper route by answering questions about facts and opinions!

Extra! Extra! is an educational children's game, designed to teach players to distinguish between fact and opinion. Players start the game with five newspaper tokens each. On a turn, they choose a card, read the passage on the card and then attempt to answer the associated question. Correct answers allow the player to roll a die and move. Wrong answers cause loss of a turn. Players attempt to land on purple spaces, which are attached to houses and allow them to "deliver" one of their newspapers. However, they may not deliver to a house that already has a paper. A few spaces contain special instructions, such as extra turns or moves or loss of turns or taking a paper back. The first player to deliver all his/her papers wins.

Description from the designer:

Empires is a drafting game, where each card has four quadrants. When a player plays a card, he or she plays it in one of these four quadrants, and it has a different effect depending on which quadrant it is placed in.

There is a buying phase after the drafting phase each round, where players will purchase upgrades.

Game Bio:
Become the leader of a local church, and grow it into the largest, most influential church in the country. Bring in money, sell books, and build additions on to your building, all to attract more and more followers.
The player with the most followers and the largest empire at the end of the game is the winner!

name.value: Mikan de Kyatto (みかんdeキャッと)

item.description:
This is a small compilation of FlipFlop 3×3, FlipFlop 5×5, and FlipFour, all playable with the same board and components. The games of the compilation utilize the components as follows:

 FlipFlop 5×5 uses the entire 5×5 board, and each player uses 5 pieces.
 FlipFlop 3×3 uses just the inner 3×3 portion of the board, and each player uses 3 pieces.
 FlipFour uses the the entire 5×5 board, and each player uses 4 pieces.

The "Geek Out! Argentina" community reunites people with very particular hobbies, which are represented in the different faces of it's logo die (comics, sci-fi, fantasy, boardgames and videogames).
The objective of the game is to gain the most points by getting dice with the "42" face. Why "42"? Because according Douglas Adams famous novel "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy", "42" is the answer to the question of the meaning of life, the universe and everything else.
But it won't be so easy since once you roll the dice EVERY die must be activated: Meeples re-roll a die, Spaceships destroys it and Super Heroes reveal it's hidden side. Fortunately Hearts give an extra die, but there are also Dragons, who will make you lose your turn.
Geek Out Masters is a fast and dynamic game, that combines strategy and luck. Are you ready to start the quest of the magic number?

Geek Out Masters was selected by the judges and the public, in 2016, to win the contest made by the "Geek Out! Argentina" gaming community, that asked to design a game using the die in it's logo as a component of it.

item.description:
In 1796 the charismatic Irish rebel, Wolfe Tone, convinced the Revolutionary government of France and one of its finest generals, Lazare Hoche, that Ireland was poised for rebellion. Ireland would rise, he insisted, if France would only lend its support. That year, a force of 14,000 Frenchmen on 43 ships evaded the British fleet and sailed into Bantry Bay, Cork County, Ireland where rough weather forced them to abandon their operation and return to France.

Two years and three audiences with Napoleon later, Tone tried again. Three waves of French landings were planned to coordinate with a general rising of the United Irishmen (Protestant and Catholic alike) all across the island. Unfortunately, word leaked and key leaders were arrested in Dublin, triggering an early rising, quickly and brutally put down by a combination of professional troops, recently raised fencibles, local militia and orange order yeomen. The rebellion staggered on through September but only in County Wexford and later in County Mayo with minimal French support, did the rebellion meet with any success.

As for the French, the first wave of 1100 men under the able command of Jean Humbert, stormed ashore in County Mayo in August, 1798. A smaller force landed in Donegal in September under the command of Napper Tandy. Humbert enjoyed a few successes but soon surrendered to the overwhelming force Lord Cornwallis brought to bear. Soon after, Tandy abandoned the Emerald Isle when he realized he could no longer be of service to Humbert. A month later and further North off the coast of Donegal, a second wave of 3000 men under Jean Hardy and Wolfe Tone himself met with disaster. Hardy’s fleet ran afoul of the British fleet and Tone was captured. Imprisoned and condemned to hang, Tone committed suicide. The third and largest wave of French soldiers never sailed.

Without determined French support the Irish rebellion of 1798 stood little chance of success. Historically it was a bloody great uncoordinated fiasco made worse by the early demise of Tone’s benefactor, General Hoche to consumption. History might have been different if the stars had aligned, if those key Irish leaders had not been captured and their plans revealed, if the rebels had received a sizeable number of French and British arms, if Hoche had survived. If a second and even a third wave of French regulars had landed, and if those French regulars had landed while the rebellion was still vibrant, then – then, as WOLFE TONE’S RISING reveals, England would have had a serious problem.

WOLFE TONE’S RISING puts the aforementioned what-ifs into play. A short game of seven turns pits English regulars and loyalist militia against the Irish rebels and their French allies. Here, the French play a shell game with the British attempting to land troops in Ireland not once but three times. Here, unknown morale plays a vital role to the outcome of every battle. Here, Local leaders are not cookie cut-outs but individuals who enjoy unique abilities in battle. And here, each battle is assisted by a battle board utilizing fresh mechanics that make each battle a mini-game unto itself. A note on the leaders used: British and French leaders are key historical leaders, whereas Irish rebel leaders are largely representational. Anonymous loyalist leaders represent a mixture of militia and yeomen. Loyalist hierarchy was either nonexistent or too confusing to identify specific names.

"Smart milkman in pocket" in English

Promotional game for The Estonian Chamber of Agriculture and Commerce. Based on Tark Laps Taskus there are thematic pictures of cows and milk production on one side of the card and letters on another side of the card.

Turn around top card and be the first to say something that is on the picture and starting the letter from another card and You get the card as a point. If nobody can´t say anything or there is a tie the card is kept for the next round.
If the deck runs out the player with the most points is the winner.

link.value: The Estonian Chamber of Agriculture and Commerce

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Building a skyscraper is tough, but working together might be even tougher. Skyscrappers pits players against each other, only to force them to cooperate a few floors higher. Elevate your status when others fail to be the best person at NOT knocking down a tower.

In this game for 3-8 players, players will be picking cards simultaneously and stacking them on top of a tower, hopefully keeping it standing. Players could be placing cards on their own, or they could be working with the other players to stack a single card on the tower.

The player who is the best at keeping the tower standing wins!

item.description:
Rolling Loot was created to participate in the 9-card PnP contest 2017 and won 3rd place in the category "Best 3 or more Player Game".

Download it here: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B8sSkh8oEQ0GamlHYVBYYkpSREE

Rolling Loot is a light pirate themed PnP game where 2-3 player will send their pirate sloops to adventures for their next loot. But they must be quick, determined and lucky to get the treasures before a rival pirate grabs it.

Gameplay:

Cards:
There is a scoring card and eight adventure cards in the game. Each adventure card has 3 requirements/steps for a ship to travel along. If the dice rolled meet the requirements, than a ship can go on an adventure always beginning from the bottom most part of the card. For a ship to advance further on an adventure card, the dice always must match the next requirement to keep on travelling. A ship can at any time during the player's turn abandon the adventure it is on and return to the player’s ship pool. Most of the requirements/steps have a certain amount of loot the player can grab in the left side of the card. Whenever a player ever grabs the loot from the space they are on, the ship is returned in the player’s pool and an unused card is placed in such a way that the amount of loot taken is covered to indicate it is exhausted. 
There are 3 levels of cards: Level 1 – Adventures with 0 / 2 / 3 loot x3 Level 2 - Adventures with 2 / 3 / 5 loot x3 Level 3 - Adventures with 4 / 6 / 10 loot x2
 Setup:
Every player gets their colored tokens (ships) of choice and make a ships pool in front of them and also a score tracker cube and put them near the scoring card.
Shuffle the Level 1 cards separately from Level 2 and Level 3 and make 2 little decks. 
In a 2-player game turn face up in the middle of the table two (2) cards from the Level 1 deck and two (2) cards from the Level 2-3 deck. In a 3-player game turn face up in the middle of the table two (2) cards from the Level 1 deck and three (3) cards from the Level 2-3 deck. These are the current game’s adventures that players can go for to get the treasures they offer.
Players roll a die to determine the starting player. Rest of the game is played clockwise.
 Gameplay: (consists of 3 phases for the current active player)
1. Loot Phase:
Before the rolling phase the ships that have travelled in previous rounds can grab the loot from the requirement/step they are on.
When the loot is grabbed, the ship is returned in the player's ships pool and an unused card is placed in such a way that this amount of loot printed on the card is covered to indicate it is exhausted.
If 2 or more ships are on the same step the loot is split between them rounded down. If the loot is the highest one at that time on the card, than it is split and taken immediately by all the players.
If there is a higher step that can be accomplished the non-active player decided if he wants to take his cut from the loot or keep his ship on the step it is on and let the active player take the whole loot.
When the last available loot is grabbed from an adventure card, all ships on this card returned to players' ships pools and the card is turned face down and is inaccessible. 
2. Rolling Phase:
The current player gets the 5 dice and rolls them.
Then he decides if he wants to keep some or all of the current dice results and/or he may reroll any combination of dice twice.
The last reroll dice results must be kept as there are.
The smallest combination that can be used for a requirement is of at least 2 dice*.

 For the “no even dice” and “no odd dice” steps in the Level 2 cards all unused dice of this round are used to fulfill this requirement.




3. Travel Phase:
After the player decides to stop rerolling or after his last reroll he chooses where he wants to send his ships according to the dice results. 
He can send both ships to adventures using the dice results.
Each die may be used only once.
A ship always begins from the 1st requirement/step (bottom part) of the card. 
A ship can travel many times during a round.
The ships of a player can be on the same card or on different ones. 
Both ships of a player may be on the same card but never on the same step of that card.
 
Game End and Scoring:
When 2 or less cards remain in game with just 1 available loot step on them, the end game is triggered. All players will play one last round. After that last round, all the ships on adventures automatically grabs the loot from the step they are on if available. 
The player who has the most loot wins. 
Tie Breaker
If 2 or more players have the same amount of loot, the player who got his amount of loot first is the winner. 
To keep track of who got first the x amount of loot, when there is more than one player in a loot space place the scoring cubes one on top of the other to indicate the order of them.

link.value: 9 Card Game Print and Play Design Contest

item.description:
In Terminus Breach TD, a semi-cooperative tower defense board game for 1-4 players, you play as one of 12 Generals defending against 15 waves of enemy Drakka. Set up a map on the fully modular board, build your starting towers, and prepare for battle!

Each wave is a turn, and consists of five phases:

Phase 1 – ADVANCE the Drakka on the board, further along the path.
Phase 2 – DRAW new Drakka to the path as they enter the battlefield.
Phase 3 – DEFEND by using your towers to damage, poison, or slow Drakka.
Phase 4 – RESOLVE by collecting Bounty, petitioning the Emperor for aid, or receiving Imperial Favors and Sanctions.
Phase 5 – DEVELOP your defenses by building new towers and upgrading your existing towers.

Every 3 waves is a Battle, and at the end of each is a powerful Boss with unique abilities.

Use the Lull between Battles to collect Victory Points, receive benefits from War Chests and Spy Networks, and place the next Battle deck - each with five new, faster, stronger Drakka.

If enough Drakka get through your defenses to cause a widespread panic, the Emperor will recall the armies and the game ends.

Survive all 15 Waves and clear the board without that happening, and you've successfully defended your homeland!

item.description: The game re-themes Funny Bunny with groundhoges, who have to hide from an eagle. Groundhog-pawns are moved heading to the finish and number of spaces are determined by a deck of cards, just like in the original. What distinguishes this game is, that multiple pawns have to be brought to the end spaces, and that a speed element is added to the game. Whenever an eagle card is revealed, a button is pressed, which randomly might activate the eagle. Players are supposed to only hide their groundhogs, if the eagle takes off from behind a bush.

Assault – Red Horizon 41

is the first volume in a series of tactical level wargames in which players lead historical units into battle during Operation Barbarossa (June through October 1941). Two factions – the German Army and the Soviet army – fight one another by use of infantry, artillery and armored units.

Assault - Red Horizon 41 is intentionally not an accurate simulation of reality, but rather it abstracts certain aspects in favor of playability and duration to convey the feeling of comprehensive tactical combat situations.

Game Mechanics and rules: 

Assault – Red Horizon 41 is a turn-based, semi-historical system with a modular rule-set. A Turn consists of 5 different Phases: Initiative, Planning, Support, Action, and Organization. Players must use the Command points to activate the units in order to achieve the goals and victory conditions. Combat is resolved using six-sided customized symbolic dice in conjunction with cards. Overall, the Assault game system is modular: the rule-set contains basic-, unit-specific-, and optional rules to help beginners delve into the game and in the various maps can be assembled as desired to form new scenarios.

What makes the game different from the competition: 

Basically, the Assault game system is completely modular and encompassing with the gamer. There are different scenarios that the players can choose and within these scenarios, the units that are available for the player to use can vary, and this is determined by the Formation cards. In each scenario, the players are given the option to choose random Formation cards (infantry, artillery, or armor/vehicle) based on their faction (this modularity will be a foundation for a strategic-level Campaign System at a later date). The Formation cards chosen list the units available for the scenario. This ensures variation and regular surprises. It’s as if your high command has assigned you certain units to achieve a goal, so you will have to adjust your individual tactics based on the available units and objectives.

Units in the Assault system are activated by Command points. Players receive a certain number of Command points, which are listed on the Formation cards. Before Command Phase, players secretly decide (behind a small screen or divider) which units to activate in the current turn. The Command point number allows the player to activate approximately 75% of all available units. Thus, players must set priorities for the turn. Not only does this speed up the game play, since all units are not used in each turn, but it also makes for some exciting moments in the fight.

In the Assault game system, we have tried to minimize the counter stacking issue. With many game systems in the hobby, you can find towers of counters and markers on certain hexes of the game board. The overview is then quickly lost. In Assault, there is a clear limit of one unit counter per hex, with the exception being the transport of units. In addition, there is usually only one command and/or status marker. Regarding Command Markers, we have devised a simple double-marker system: each marker is double-sided and after the end of the round, in the Organization Phase, the markers are flipped or removed according to their color. This goes pretty quickly.
In general, Assault paid more attention to game flow. The fact that Command Points are assigned to activate units in the Planning Phase accelerates the game. Since the units to be activated are already established before the Action Phase, there is less for the player to think about and fewer opportunities for AP to set in.

Overall, the Assault system is modular and can be expanded as desired. A game can be finished on a single map piece in 1 to 2 hours. If you have more time available, you can also take an entire day for a battle using larger maps with multiple tiles. Players should be able to learn the game rather quickly. The basic rules are fixed and future expansions will not lead to new rule flooding and make the game confusing.

What is the level of detail and the level of the player:

I would describe the level of detail for the Assault system as “medium.” This also applies to newcomers to the wargaming hobby. Test results so far show that playing Assault becomes increasingly interesting because experience gained in the game can be converted into goal-oriented decisions in future games. This means that players who already understand the various properties of the units, terrain, and the combination of possibilities will naturally have an advantage. 
 For this, we have also created a small start-up aid. For each unit in the game, there is a profile with historical fact and also included is a brief description of how these can be used tactically in the game. This can also be of use to those players not deeply versed in military history and technology.

What is in the box (preliminary):
To this end, we have created prototype with the following scope:
1 x design rules booklet
3 x Combat / Scenario Cards
2 x playing aids
9 x map tiles
1 x round marker
1 x round indicator
4 x target field markers
4 x neutral / waypoint markers
2 x Initiative Cube
22 x formation cards
32 x unit cards
36 x command cards
24 x battle cubes
15 x damage markers
20 x fog marker
26 x command points
100 x command and status markers
50 x unit marker Wehrmacht
55 x unit marker Soviet Army

Description from the publisher:

Smolensk: Barbarossa Derailed is the latest release in the Operational Combat Series (OCS), covering the campaign along the Moscow highway in the summer of 1941. These actions set the stage for the Wehrmacht’s autumn drive on the Soviet capital, and many historians believe the bitter fighting here ultimately doomed the Axis to failure in Russia.

The game begins on 8 July with Barbarossa still in high gear. In August, the advance stalls as Hitler diverts most of the panzers from the map to forces around Leningrad and Kiev. Soviet counteroffensives will push Army Group Center close to the breaking point by game’s end on 8 September. The asymmetry of the two armies will be familiar to veterans of past OCS campaigns, especially Guderian’s Blitzkrieg II. There is the expected qualitative difference in typical Action Ratings, along with stark contrasts in logistical capabilities and replacement rates. There also some unique twists in the situation, including:


 Three of the panzer divisions are getting their first taste of combat, so their Action Ratings are reduced.
 The rivalry between Heinz Guderian and Hermann Hoth makes it difficult for these generals to coordinate their panzer armies, and might prevent the ring from closing around Smolensk.
 Soviet tank divisions are shown for the first time. They pack a wallop, but their quality leaves a lot to be desired.
 The Soviet 1st Motorized Division is presented as a somewhat elite multi-unit formation that includes some heavy KV-1s and T-34s.
 The contributions of small militia, tank, and anti-tank units are reflected by the Soviet Alarm Pool.
 Other chrome accounts for ‘tree bark soup’ (used by cut-off units), planes diverted to terror-bomb Moscow, and special markers for artillery ammo & katyusha effects.


Smolensk is a small and fairly simple entry in the series, with special rules kept to a minimum. We think players will enjoy the fact both sides must attack and defend. By the end they will learn three things about this campaign: the Soviets are more than just punching bags, the Germans are challenged to hold their early gains,
and the road to Moscow will be paved in blood.

Seven scenarios are included:
Intro Scenario: Vitebsk, 1/2 turn, using about 1/4 of the map
Smolensk Campaign, 8 July to 8 September (19 turns)
Late July Start, 22 July to 8 September (15 turns)
1st Counteroffensive, 22 July to 1 August (4 turns)
Early August Start, 8 August to 8 September (10 turns)
2nd Counteroffensive, 8 August to 22 August (5 turns)
3rd Counteroffensive, 26 August to 8 September (5 turns)

item.description:
Panzer Attack: War in Russia is a fast-paced, easy to learn, deck building, card game that captures the epic scope of World War 2 combat on the Eastern Front. The core game abstractly simulates the war between Germany and the USSR between 1941 and 1945, and the territory cards included allow players to fight along Army Group Center's path between Berlin and Moscow. Additional add-on modules add more cards for greater customization possibilities, and open up new campaign options.

The game uses deckbuilding aspects that allow players to customize their deck to fit their preferred play style, and features play that only requires the cards themselves in order to play a game.

The objective of the game is to either destroy all of your opponent's forces in play, or capture all territories on the board. This is done using troop and unit cards that represent the troops, equipment and historical units that fought in the war, in addition to action and leader cards that add variability and an extra layer of strategy to the game.

In this deliciously gooey card game, you’ll build (or rebuild as needed) your body from a severed head, equip yourself with a motley collection of weapons and armor, and eventually behead the Chief of the Zombie Nest to take over leadership and win the game.

As a zombie, losing your head doesn’t kill you, but it sure can put a damper on your day. It’ll take time to forage and scavenge enough material to build a new body, but you’re determined to do it. Maybe you’ll get lucky and find some useful tools, maybe even a weapon or two.

It’s not going to be easy, because the other Players are all trying to do the same thing. Will you be lucky enough to find the chainsaw and the shotgun? Will some other zombie trick you at the last second into walking into helicopter blades? There’s only one way to find out!

Regardless, you’re not the kind of zombie that’s going to let a little beheading get between you and your ultimate goal: to rule the Zombie Tribe!

Description from the publisher:

Warforged: First Contact is a skirmish-level exploration game where the Iron Legionaries of the Terran Authority investigate a dimension-spanning shrine-portal of the alien Mantra. The Iron Legion will need to use tight coordination and clever tactics to overcome the limitless hordes of the Mantra and battle their way to the heart of the shrine-portal.


 2+ Players using Iron Legion versus the Mantra (additional players take command of separate Iron Legion squads; the Mantra player acts as "dungeon master"). 
 20-60 minutes play time depending on the scenario.
 Unique and accessible command card activation system. 
 A wide selection of friends and enemies to use from lowly expendables to mighty heroes. 
 Traps, alien conditions and reinforcements shift the odds through a game. Victory is rarely assured and games remain exciting to the last throw of the dice.

item.description:
You are an alchemist for "The Kingdom". In order to keep your job and become the Royal Alchemist you must make the most "Coin" for the Treasury. Starting with only Air, Earth, Fire, and Water as ingredients, play Formula cards from your hand to make valuable Materials. These Materials are worth Coin towards winning, but can also be used as ingredients for Formulas that steal, transform, destroy or regenerate cards.
 Alchenemy combines elements of resource management (cards that count towards winning can be discarded to perform actions), “take that!” (inevitably, someone breaks out the Aqua Regia and dissolves something you were really attached to), and a novel mechanic that gives players some control over when the game ends: you choose whether to draw from a common, limitless deck of basic resources or a limited, personal deck of more powerful cards – with the catch that the game ends when any personal stack is exhausted. Two, three, or four people may play and it should take first time players about an hour to finish.

Description from the publisher:

Gyrating Hamsters is a hilarious, fast paced, interactive, hamster themed card game. GH is designed for 2-5 players and takes about 30min to play. The object of the game is to grow your hamster horde to the hamster threshold.

Card Type: With 5 unique card types and numerous variations there is light strategy with heavy replayability. Card types include Horde Hamsters, Attack Hamsters, Actions Cards, Chaos Cards, and of course, the Gyrating Hamster.

Gameplay: Each turn consists of drawing and playing combinations of hamsters and actions to build your own Hamster Horde, while depleting other Hordes. At the end of their turn, players have the option of combatting opponents directly in winner-take-all battles.

Strategy: To be successful, players must balance building their horde, managing their hand, defending their hamsters, and attacking their opponents. The game is over when the threshold of hamsters is obtained by 1 player.

A spelling card game that helps to improve your spelling, expand your vocabulary & have hours of fun competing with all your friends and families.

Somewhat in the style of a card based scrabble, each player takes turns taking 3 actions where they can either play a word, draw a card from the deck or a "spell field", or steal a card from another player's word.

The game ends when a player makes 5 words to which the final round is played. The winner is determined by the score from the words created. Words that uses 5 cards or more will score higher.

Players can also use various power cards which does various effects from drawing extra cards to stealing more than one cards from another player

Economy Class is a stock-trading themed card game. The game is played over two phases. In the first phase players auction cards to build a hand. In the second they play half of their hand (through simultaneous card play) to manipulate the stock market before selling off the second half of the cards in their hand at the end of the game. The player with the most money at the end wins.

item.description:
Bottle Flip is a dexterity game where players attempt to flip a bottle onto a target according to different challenge cards. Players move along a scoring track after successfully completing flip challenges.

Types of Bottle Flip challenges include:
Individual Challenges
Face-To-Face “Flip Offs”
Group “All Out Flip Outs”
Create Your Own Challenges

Challenge examples:
-Flip and land a bottle using only your elbows
-1 attempt to land 6 bottle flips before you blink

English Description:

The crazy Catalans are at it again, creating massive human towers in streets and squares. Your team of castellers, called colles, tries to raise up their towers first with encouragement from the Grallers (musicians) and the Cap de colla (team leader). Careful not to get the jitters and try to avoid llenya (when your tower falls down). The festival winner is the colla who gets the most applause!

This is a card game which takes 20 minutes to play where you build human towers through hand management. Turns are played clockwise, with each player being able to either take a group of castellers from the table, take two cards from the deck, or raise part of their human tower.

To win the game, you must have the most points (or applause). The points are won throughout the game, the player who raises one of the towers first gets 4 points, if that tower is built by another player, they will only receive 3 points, the next 2 points, and the last player 1 point.

Once a player has risen 3 towers, the game ends and the points are counted.

The game is the various phases of a game of sport fishing. Advances on the path to the fisherman, choose the most favorable fishing spot, mount the barrel, choose the bait, the float, the toggle and line. After that it faces a real fishing action: if a fish bites can catch it only if you have just installed your fishing rod. In the end who will win to his credit as many kilograms of fish.

INTERNATIONAL CAMPAIGN CURRENTLY ON KICKSTARTER!>> https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1460598061/warlords-of-terra-the-battlefield-faction-card-gam/description

Warlords of Terra has been classified as BFCG or Battlefield Faction Card Game, due to its main difference in game mechanics: there exists a REAL BATTLEFIELD in which our troops will have to move and cross, for us to reach our opponent's lines and defeat them. Moreover "Faction" means that the product format is sold according to the different kingdoms or factions. New expansion sets come in new boxes containing FULL PLAYSET (not only 1-2 copies) of new cards for its corresponding faction or an alliance of 2 kingdoms. So, it's not necessary acquiring the full expansion if only an specific kingdom is wanted.

If you like classic Card Games mechanics but want something really NEW, and a true new strategic component which will make you develop your strategies at a higher level, this is your game.

Both players start with 20 life points, and our goal is reducing opponent's life to 0 or below. But to achieve that we need to cast our troops in our invocation line (first line)and cross with them all the battlefield, fighting enemy troops to reach their lines and "hit" them equal to our troops ATK value. As said, 20 points means victory. The fact troops need to move makes them have an unusual basic value: they have ATTACK/LIFE and SPEED (number of zones -cells- they can run in a turn).

But troops, objects and the rest of cards aren't played for free. It's fundamental to produce mana and gold for that. With this purpose, we will build "Place" cards with a cost and production amount. So, each turn we will add mana and gold equal to 1 plus the production indicated by our place cards. A good curve in resources production means a good match development, and that will make us stronger.

Important: place cards are separated from "battle cards" (the rest: troops, objects, spells...), for us to choose what we want to draw each turn.

In a players' phase, they prepare all "turned" (exhausted) cards, add resources, build places, invoke troops or forge objects, then go to tactical phase, in which they can move troops one by one, cast spells, play hero skills, equip objects, fight against enemy troops or hit enemy player.

Sudden spells can be also played in response to opponent's actions, in order to disable their strategy.

A 1vs1 game which would charm any card+strategy game lover.

We summarize it with a single sentence: 
END OF GAME. CHALLENGE BEGINS.

item.description:
Up & Down is a trick-taking game which uses a traditional 52-card deck (1-13 in four suits), one special double-sided Up and Down Card as well as two dice.

Players compete over multiple rounds based on the number of players. Players are dealt a hand of cards. The number of cards depends on the number of players. The trump is determined by rolling the two dice (the trump is always between 2-12). Players win the trick if they play the highest or lowest card depending on the special Up & Down Card.

The player with the most tricks at the end of the game is declared the winner.

Players compete in two teams in Decrypto, with each trying to correctly interpret the coded messages presented to them by their teammates while cracking the codes they intercept from the opposing team.

In more detail, each team has their own screen, and in this screen they tuck four cards in pockets numbered 1-4, letting everyone on the same team see the words on these cards while hiding the words from the opposing team. In the first round, each team does the following: One team member takes a code card that shows three of the digits 1-4 in some order, e.g., 4-2-1. They then give a coded message that their teammates must use to guess this code. For example, if the team's four words are "pig", "candy", "tent", and "son", then I might say "Sam-striped-pink" and hope that my teammates can correctly map those words to 4-2-1. If they guess correctly, great; if not, we receive a black mark of failure.

Starting in the second round, a member of each team must again give a clue about their words to match a numbered code. If I get 2-4-3, I might now say, "sucker-prince-stake". The other team then attempts to guess our numbered code. If they're correct, they receive a white mark of success; if not, then my team must guess the number correctly or take a black mark of failure. (Guessing correctly does nothing except avoid failure and give the opposing team information about what our hidden words might be.)

The rounds continue until a team collects either its second white mark (winning the game) or its second black mark (losing the game). Games typically last between 4-7 rounds. If neither team has won after eight rounds, then each team must attempt to guess the other team's words; whichever team guesses more words correctly wins.

item.description:
A casual and fast card game extracted from the Living Starship universe where each player is a ship captain vying to have their crew complete the most work to earn the admiral's attention.

The game is for 3-7 players and features a hexagonal deck of 98 cards that come in each of the seven Fleet Divisions (suits): Agency, Flight, Engineering, Health, Operations, Science and Tactical. Each suit has 14 cards - 7 officers and 7 enlisted.

Each round there is an increasing number of mission tokens (points) to be claimed by the crew cards. Officer cards always outwork (claim tokens of the same color) enlisted cards, even if their numerical value is lower, but they can only be played in singles. For the cost of one of your points, you can play a pair of enlisted whose value exceeds an officer's of the same color/suit and take their claimed mission tokens.

The deck is seeded with 7 SETBACK cards and the game ends when the last one is drawn. The player with the most points accumulated from claiming job tokens is the winner and is hailed by the admiralty as the most formidable captain in the Fleet.

Rec-League Quidditch is an exciting quidditch-themed tile-placement game with some elements of skill-building and risk analysis for two players. During the game, each player will control three characters on a team. These characters will compete for control of the quidditch pitch, using the quaffle, bludger, and snitch to score points, as well as continually improving their strength, speed, and skill to win the match.

Each round is played by placing the character tiles in a line on the pitch, in between tiles representing the three quidditch balls. The location on the line,as well as the particular ball that each character is adjacent to will determine the possible action they can take for the round. Once all characters have been placed, they are activated by either using adjacent ball tiles to score points, or using them to build up their strength, speed, or skill.

Furthermore, one character on each team will be the designated seeker, and will be hunting down the snitch. Catching the snitch will take not only skill, but a little luck as well, so players would be wise to make sure they time their attempts to catch the snitch when it would only be to their advantage, and not their opponent's.

Catching the snitch awards a team 50 points, and the game is over after the round ends in which either the snitch is caught, or one team has scored at least 150 points total. The winner is the team with the most points at the end.

link.value: 2017 Two-Player Print and Play Game Design Contest

item.description:
Arrange a unit of humanoid robots, select weapons, and edit your tactics!

CHRONO BLAZE'' (ã‚¯ ãƒ­ ãƒŽ ãƒ– ãƒ¬ ã‚¤ ã‚º)" is a full-scale card game of the main theme computer!

Divide the 36 decks into two players, take their weapons with limited resources, repair the mechanics, and drive the battlefield!

The aircraft has a "Captain" and a "Wardrobe." The two players decide whether to use "Blind Type" or "Mighty Type" at the beginning of the game.

Place your equipment on your turn and use it.

If you destroy all of your opponent's gas, you win.

The key to winning and losing is a calm judgment and an accurate reading ... ... But as time comes "Luck (Ruck)" and "Unlucky (ã‚¢ ãƒ³ ãƒ© ãƒƒ ã‚¯)" all swallow!

I will release a new sensory robot battle this spring as a model!

Contents

36 cards (for 2 people)

One instruction book


 The four-player competition is an extension rule, and two sets of these are required.



 The game requires two separate 6 pieces of dice (due to packing, it is not possible to bundle the dice that were predicted in the early days, but it will be accepted)

name.value: Challenge Golden Bell OX Quiz game

item.description:
Proceed to the voice of the challenger Golden Bell TV host.
challenge mode and single mode support.

The game consists of three rounds in total.
Each round is made up of OX quiz.

Round 1: All Participation Quiz
Round 2: Individual Quiz
Round 3: Speed Quiz

The purpose of the game is to match the golden bell quiz. The 50th quiz.

At the end of Question 49, the person with the highest score challenges the Golden Bell Quiz.

There is no middle drop.
The winner of the Golden Bell quiz will win.

Masterwork
A beautiful game of creating prestigious artworks

In Masterwork, players are artists struggling to win prestige by creating famous artworks and participating in gallery exhibitions. Collect pigments to craft brilliant paints and use those paints to paint the greatest artworks of the High Renaissance. Get critiqued, build your portfolio, and exhibit your work to become the most prestigious artist of the period!


It's your turn
On your turn, if you haven’t started an artwork, you may select one from the gallery and move it to your easel, indicating that artwork is in progress. Now, only you can complete it. Next, use sets of pigments from your hand to produce paint, discarding the requisite cards indicated in the recipe area on the paint card. Move your new paint from the palette to your hand or place it on your easel, dedicating it to that artwork.

Each artwork requires a specific set of paints. When you have gathered them, in hand or on the easel, it’s time to submit your artwork for a critique. Roll the critique die; if the value of equal or higher to the prestige value of the artwork, you have successfully completed it! Move the artwork, along with all paints used to complete it, to the table, clearing your easel for your next artwork. If your roll came up short, take a feedback token indicating you’ve received useful advice from the critique. This token makes future critique attempts easier. Each subsequent artwork makes future critiques easier, representing the artist’s growing popularity.

All 24 artwork cards award prestige points, with addition prestige earned by participating in exhibitions. Exhibits award prestige points when players complete sets of artwork cards; such as: ‘Leonardo Exhibit’ (two artworks from Leonardo da Vinci) and ‘Portrait Exhibit’ (artworks featuring portrait images). Masterwork includes 16 exhibit cards, with a random set of three used each game, offering a great deal of replayability.


Mixing colors
Pairs of primary color (Red, Yellow, Blue) cards may mix to be played as a secondary card of the same type. Secondary colors (Orange, Green, Violet) and different card types (Pigment and Paint cards) do not mix. Mixing colors gives you creative options when producing Pigment and Paint cards. Remember: you must always mix the same type (Paint with Paint, etc.)


Ending and scoring
When a player completes a gold-edged Masterwork Artwork card, finish the current round so each player has an equal number of turns (the player to the right of the starting player gets the final play). Each player adds up the Prestige Points from their completed Artwork cards. The three Exhibit cards are evaluated one after another for each player, comparing their completed Artwork cards with the requirements of cards. For each completed Exhibit card, add the indicated Prestige Point value to the Player’s total. The player with the most Prestige Points wins!

Daedalus was the architect in charge of designing the labyrinth of Crete to enclosure on it the Minotaur. Now it is you who have been thrown into the labyrinth. Only one can escape in time. Will it be you?

In Dedalo's your objective is to escape from the labyrinth while you prevent your rivals from doing it before you.

Dedalo's is a competitive board game of 2 to 6 players. The games last approximately 20-30 minutes and each one is different from the previous one. It is a game with very simple rules and agile to play.

All players start in the same tile and the first one in getting to one of the exit tiles win. On their turn players must place tiles to create their own path to an exit or block their opponents path and move their own character. All that while the Minotaur could show up and create some danger for them.
